refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The GtkSourceBuffer object is the model for GtkSourceView widgets. It extends the GtkTextBuffer object by adding features necessary to display and edit source code: syntax highlighting, bracket matching and markers. It also implements support for undo/redo operations.
To create a GtkSourceBuffer use gtk_source_buffer_new() or gtk_source_buffer_new_with_language(). The second form is just a convenience function which allows you to initially set a GtkSourceLanguage.

By default highlighting is enabled, but you can disable it with gtk_source_buffer_set_highlight(). This can be useful if you're not using GtkSourceLanguage objects to set the highlighting patterns, and instead you're manually adding GtkSourceTag objects to the buffer's tag table.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_new ()
refsect2.para: Creates a new source buffer.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceTagTable, or NULL to create a new one.
a new source buffer.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_new_with_language ()
refsect2.para: Creates a new source buffer using the highlighting patterns in language. This is equivalent to creating a new source buffer with the default tag table and then calling gtk_source_buffer_set_language().

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceLanguage.
a new source buffer which will highlight text according to language.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_get_check_brackets ()
refsect2.para: Determines whether bracket match highlighting is activated for the source buffer.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
TRUE if the source buffer will highlight matching brackets.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_set_check_brackets ()
refsect2.para: Controls the bracket match highlighting function in the buffer. If activated, when you position your cursor over a bracket character (a parenthesis, a square bracket, etc.) the matching opening or closing bracket character will be highlighted. You can specify the style with the gtk_source_buffer_set_bracket_match_style() function.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
TRUE if you want matching brackets highlighted.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_set_bracket_match_style ()
refsect2.para: Sets the style used for highlighting matching brackets.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
the GtkSourceTagStyle specifying colors and text attributes.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_get_highlight ()
refsect2.para: Determines whether text highlighting is activated in the source buffer.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
TRUE if highlighting is enabled.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_set_highlight ()
refsect2.para: Controls whether text is highlighted in the buffer. If highlight is TRUE, the text will be highlighted according to the patterns installed in the buffer (either set with gtk_source_buffer_set_language() or by adding individual GtkSourceTag tags to the buffer's tag table). Otherwise, any current highlighted text will be restored to the default buffer style.
Tags not of GtkSourceTag type will not be removed by this option, and normal GtkTextTag priority settings apply when highlighting is enabled.

If not using a GtkSourceLanguage for setting the highlighting patterns in the buffer, it is recommended for performance reasons that you add all the GtkSourceTag tags with highlighting disabled and enable it when finished.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
TRUE if you want to activate highlighting.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_get_max_undo_levels ()
refsect2.para: Determines the number of undo levels the buffer will track for buffer edits.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
the maximum number of possible undo levels.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_set_max_undo_levels ()
refsect2.para: Sets the number of undo levels for user actions the buffer will track. If the number of user actions exceeds the limit set by this function, older actions will be discarded.

A new action is started whenever the function gtk_text_buffer_begin_user_action() is called. In general, this happens whenever the user presses any key which modifies the buffer, but the undo manager will try to merge similar consecutive actions, such as multiple character insertions into one action. But, inserting a newline does start a new action.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
the desired maximum number of undo levels.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_get_language ()
refsect2.para: Determines the GtkSourceLanguage used by the buffer. The returned object should not be unreferenced by the user.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
the GtkSourceLanguage set by gtk_source_buffer_set_language(), or NULL.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_set_language ()
refsect2.para: Sets the GtkSourceLanguage the source buffer will use, adding GtkSourceTag tags with the language's patterns and setting the escape character with gtk_source_buffer_set_escape_char(). Note that this will remove any GtkSourceTag tags currently in the buffer's tag table. The buffer holds a reference to the language set.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
a GtkSourceLanguage to set, or NULL.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_get_escape_char ()
refsect2.para: Determines the escaping character used by the source buffer highlighting engine.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
the UTF-8 character for the escape character the buffer is using.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_set_escape_char ()
refsect2.para: Sets the escape character to be used by the highlighting engine.

When performing the initial analysis, the engine will discard a matching syntax pattern if it's prefixed with an odd number of escape characters. This allows for example to correctly highlight strings with escaped quotes embedded.
This setting affects only syntax patterns (i.e. those defined in GtkSyntaxTag tags).

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
the escape character the buffer should use.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_can_undo ()
refsect2.para: Determines whether a source buffer can undo the last action.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
TRUE if it's possible to undo the last action.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_can_redo ()
refsect2.para: Determines whether a source buffer can redo the last action (i.e. if the last operation was an undo).

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
TRUE if a redo is possible.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_undo ()
refsect2.para: Undoes the last user action which modified the buffer. Use gtk_source_buffer_can_undo() to check whether a call to this function will have any effect.

Actions are defined as groups of operations between a call to gtk_text_buffer_begin_user_action() and gtk_text_buffer_end_user_action(), or sequences of similar edits (inserts or deletes) on the same line.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_redo ()
refsect2.para: Redoes the last undo operation. Use gtk_source_buffer_can_redo() to check whether a call to this function will have any effect.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_begin_not_undoable_action ()
refsect2.para: Marks the beginning of a not undoable action on the buffer, disabling the undo manager. Typically you would call this function before initially setting the contents of the buffer (e.g. when loading a file in a text editor).
You may nest gtk_source_buffer_begin_not_undoable_action() / gtk_source_buffer_end_not_undoable_action() blocks.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_end_not_undoable_action ()
refsect2.para: Marks the end of a not undoable action on the buffer. When the last not undoable block is closed through the call to this function, the list of undo actions is cleared and the undo manager is re-enabled.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_create_marker ()
refsect2.programlisting: GtkSourceMarker* gtk_source_buffer_create_marker (GtkSourceBuffer *buffer, const gchar *name, const gchar *type, const GtkTextIter *where);
refsect2.para: Creates a marker in the buffer of type type. A marker is semantically very similar to a GtkTextMark, except it has a type which is used by the GtkSourceView displaying the buffer to show a pixmap on the left margin, at the line the marker is in. Because of this, a marker is generally associated to a line and not a character position. Markers are also accessible through a position or range in the buffer.
Markers are implemented using GtkTextMark, so all characteristics and restrictions to marks apply to markers too. These includes life cycle issues and "mark-set" and "mark-deleted" signal emissions.
Like a GtkTextMark, a GtkSourceMarker can be anonymous if the passed name is NULL. Also, the buffer owns the markers so you shouldn't unreference it.

Markers always have left gravity and are moved to the beginning of the line when the user deletes the line they were in. Also, if the user deletes a region of text which contained lines with markers, those are deleted.
Typical uses for a marker are bookmarks, breakpoints, current executing instruction indication in a source file, etc..

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
the name of the marker, or NULL.
a string defining the marker type, or NULL.
location to place the marker.
a new GtkSourceMarker, owned by the buffer.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_move_marker ()
refsect2.para: Moves marker to the new location where.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
a GtkSourceMarker in buffer.
the new location for the marker.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_delete_marker ()
refsect2.para: Deletes marker from the source buffer. The same conditions as for GtkTextMark apply here. The marker is no longer accessible from the buffer, but if you held a reference to it, it will not be destroyed.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
a GtkSourceMarker in the buffer.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_get_marker ()
refsect2.para: Looks up the GtkSourceMarker named name in buffer, returning NULL if it doesn't exists.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
name of the marker to retrieve.
the GtkSourceMarker whose name is name, or NULL.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_get_markers_in_region ()
refsect2.programlisting: GSList* gtk_source_buffer_get_markers_in_region (GtkSourceBuffer *buffer, const GtkTextIter *begin, const GtkTextIter *end);
refsect2.para: Returns an ordered (by position) GSList of GtkSourceMarker objects inside the region delimited by the GtkTextIter begin and end. The iters may be in any order.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
beginning of the range.
end of the range.
a GSList of the GtkSourceMarker inside the range.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_get_first_marker ()
refsect2.para: Returns the first (nearest to the top of the buffer) marker in buffer.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
a reference to the first GtkSourceMarker, or NULL if there are no markers in the buffer.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_get_last_marker ()
refsect2.para: Returns the last (nearest to the bottom of the buffer) marker in buffer.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
a reference to the last GtkSourceMarker, or NULL if there are no markers in the buffer.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_get_iter_at_marker ()
refsect2.para: Initializes iter at the location of marker.

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
a GtkTextIter to initialize.
a GtkSourceMarker of buffer.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_get_next_marker ()
refsect2.para: Returns the nearest marker to the right of iter. If there are multiple markers at the same position, this function will always return the first one (from the internal linked list), even if starting the search exactly at its location. You can get the others using gtk_source_marker_next().

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
the location to start searching from.
the GtkSourceMarker nearest to the right of iter, or NULL if there are no more markers after iter.

refsect2.title: gtk_source_buffer_get_prev_marker ()
refsect2.para: Returns the nearest marker to the left of iter. If there are multiple markers at the same position, this function will always return the last one (from the internal linked list), even if starting the search exactly at its location. You can get the others using gtk_source_marker_prev().

listitem.simpara: a GtkSourceBuffer.
the location to start searching from.
the GtkSourceMarker nearest to the left of iter, or NULL if there are no more markers before iter.

refsect2.title: The "check-brackets" property
refsect2.para: Whether to check and highlight matching brackets.
Default value: TRUE

refsect2.title: The "escape-char" property
refsect2.para: Escaping character for syntax patterns.
Default value: 0

refsect2.title: The "highlight" property
refsect2.para: Whether to highlight syntax in the buffer.
Default value: FALSE

refsect2.title: The "language" property
refsect2.para: Language object to get highlighting patterns from.

refsect2.title: The "max-undo-levels" property
refsect2.para: Number of undo levels for the buffer.
Allowed values: [0,200]
Default value: 25

refsect2.title: The "can-redo" signal
refsect2.para: Emitted whenever there is a change in the buffer's ability to redo an operation.

listitem.simpara: the object which received the signal.
TRUE if the buffer can now perform an redo.
user data set when the signal handler was connected.

refsect2.title: The "can-undo" signal
refsect2.para: Emitted whenever there is a change in the buffer's ability to undo an operation.

listitem.simpara: the object which received the signal.
TRUE if the buffer can now perform an undo.
user data set when the signal handler was connected.

refsect2.title: The "highlight-updated" signal
refsect2.programlisting: void user_function (GtkSourceBuffer *sourcebuffer, GtkTextIter *arg1, GtkTextIter *arg2, gpointer user_data);
refsect2.para: Emitted whenever the syntax highlighting information has been updated, so that views can request a redraw if the region changed is visible. Usually only view widgets displaying this buffer will be interested in this signal.

listitem.simpara: the object which received the signal.
GtkTextIter at the start of the updated region.
GtkTextIter at the end of the updated region.
user data set when the signal handler was connected.

refsect2.title: The "marker-updated" signal
refsect2.para: Emitted whenever a marker of sourcebuffer has changed and needs to be redisplayed by the view. A change in a marker's type or location can trigger this signal.
Note that moving a marker causes the emission of this signal twice: one for the old location and one for the new.

listitem.simpara: the object which received the signal.
GtkTextIter at the location where the change occurred.
user data set when the signal handler was connected.

refsect1.title: See Also
refsect1.para: There is an introduction document describing the basic concepts of the buffer/view interactions.
Check GtkTextBuffer for information about the base buffer; and GtkSourceView for examples on setting up the buffer to be displayed in a view widget.
